ITEM.SENTENCE: When we taste humiliation and pain, we learn never to abase others.
She was abashed by her friend’s rude behaviour towards the old woman.
ITEM.HINT: Abash means to make someone feel embarrassed.

ITEM.SENTENCE: After two days of continuous downpour, the rain finally abated.
To abbreviate the word ‘mister’, one should write Mr.
The king of Nepal was forced to abdicate his throne when the people rebelled.
ITEM.CHOICE: Renounce a position, right, or responsibility.
ITEM.HINT: Abdicate means to renounce a position.

ITEM.SENTENCE: When drunk even a person with good manners displays aberrant behaviour.
ITEM.HINT: Aberrant means to behave in an abnormal manner.

ITEM.SENTENCE: The severe cold was an aberration from the usual weather pattern.
ITEM.HINT: Aberration means a departure from what is normal.

ITEM.SENTENCE: We should not abet others in wrong doing.
ITEM.CHOICE: Assist or encourage, usually in doing something wrong.
ITEM.HINT: Abet means to assist someone in doing something wrong.

ITEM.SENTENCE: The cricket match was held in abeyance until the rain stopped.
ITEM.HINT: Abeyance means a state of temporary suspension.

ITEM.SENTENCE: Abhor violence and sow the seeds of love and kindness.
Fearing violence the Minister acquiesced to the request of his party for a change in policy.
ITEM.HINT: Acquiesce means to agree without protesting.

ITEM.SENTENCE: He accepted the invitation to attend the course on Quality Management with alacrity.
The convenor of the programme was very amiable and greeted everyone enthusiastically.
ITEM.CHOICE: Deserving of respect because of age or achievement.

ITEM.SENTENCE: It is difficult to appease a person when he is angry.
ITEM.CHOICE: Deserving of respect because of age or achievement.

ITEM.SENTENCE: Any working procedure must be known by all and should not be arcane.
ITEM.CHOICE: Obscure, known only by a few.
ITEM.HINT: Arcane means something known only by a few

ITEM.SENTENCE: Man today seems to be driven by avarice and selfish desires, ignoring those of others.
ITEM.CHOICE: Brave in the face of danger.

ITEM.SENTENCE: Politics today is corrupted and follow a brazen approach in amassing public funds for private ends.
The service provided was a little brusque as the executive was busy.
It is easy to cajole a child with chocolates.
ITEM.CHOICE: The solemn sound of a bell, often indicating a death.

ITEM.SENTENCE: Some people have a callous disregard towards the suffering of others.
ITEM.CHOICE: Luck, finding good things without looking for them.
A preference or inclination for something.

ITEM.SENTENCE: A good leader should have professional candour and rate everyone the same.
The teacher chided the child for not completing his homework.
He was circumspect in his dealing with her, as she was known to carry tales about others.
ITEM.CHOICE: A common saying expressing a principle of conduct.

ITEM.SENTENCE: The politicians had a clandestine meeting as they did not want the media to know of it.
ITEM.CHOICE: Extremely careful with details. Clandestine means secret.

ITEM.SENTENCE: Despite having lost his job, Renjith was coerced into making his car payment by a callous bill collector.
ITEM.CHOICE: Make somebody do something by force or threat.
ITEM.HINT: Coerce means to make somebody do something by force.

ITEM.SENTENCE: Despite a head injury the patient was stable and gave coherent responses.
Complacency with health issues can lead to serious problems over time.
ITEM.CHOICE: A preference or inclination for something.
Luck, finding good things without looking for them.
Consisting of a very great number.
ITEM.HINT: Complacency means a self-satisfied ignorance of danger.

ITEM.SENTENCE: A best friend can be a trusted confidant.
ITEM.HINT: Confidant means a person entrusted with secrets

ITEM.SENTENCE: Mark's co-workers connived to bring about his downfall.
Deposits in bank are cumulative and give good interest.
Do not debase others as each person has an identity that should be respected.
ITEM.CHOICE: To lower the quality or esteem of something.
A slight variation in meaning, tone.
ITEM.HINT: Debase means to lower the esteem of others

ITEM.SENTENCE: The price rise in petrol was decried by all.
ITEM.CHOICE: A remedy for all ills or difficulties.
Lacking consciousness or awareness of something.

ITEM.SENTENCE: We should learn to be deferential to those in authority.
ITEM.CHOICE: Lacking quickness of sensibility or intellect.
ITEM.HINT: Deferential means showing respect for another’s authority.

ITEM.SENTENCE: He had a demure manner and did not talk much.
ITEM.CHOICE: Lacking quickness of sensibility or intellect.
Deserving of respect because of age or achievement.

ITEM.SENTENCE: Never deride others, it may boomerang.
ITEM.CHOICE: Lacking consciousness or awareness of something.

ITEM.SENTENCE: She is a dedicated and diligent worker.
ITEM.CHOICE: Showing care in doing one’s work.
ITEM.HINT: Diligent means showing care in doing one’s work

ITEM.SENTENCE: He was elated by the grades he obtained in the exam, and joyfully announced it to his parents.

ITEM.SENTENCE: Mother Theresa was known for her empathy, love and kindness.
ITEM.CHOICE: Sensitivity to another’s feelings as if they were one’s own.

ITEM.SENTENCE: Among animals, the mongoose and the snake are known for their enmity.

ITEM.SENTENCE: A responsible media would choose not to air programmes that depict gratuitous violence or lust.

ITEM.SENTENCE: Pride goes before destruction and a haughty spirit before a fall.
There are three things in the world that deserve no mercy: hypocrisy, fraud and tyranny.

ITEM.SENTENCE: Whatever your profession, ensure you are meticulous in your work, or you may end up having to redo it.
ITEM.HINT: Meticulous means extremely careful with details.

ITEM.SENTENCE: Though stories in fables weave themselves around fantasy, they have a modicum of truth in them.
